blogPosts.title: COVID-19: How you can help
blogPosts.summary: Watching the news cycle at the moment can cause many of us to feel hopeless. Now that many people have become accustomed to social isolation, some are looking for things they can do to help. In todayâ€™s post we share a few extra things you can do to assist in the fight against COVID-19 if you arenâ€™t a frontline worker (other than staying home).

text_1: For the last several weeks youâ€™ve been staying home, only going out when absolutely necessary and keeping up with the news. By simply staying home, you are already contributing in the fight against COVID-19. But maybe lately you have started to feel helpless and wanting to know if there is something else you can do.
Maybe you have started to ask - what am I supposed to do now?

If you have the means, detailed below are a few things you can do to help in the battle against coronavirus. Keep in mind the best thing to do is stay home as much as possible; the list below consists of â€˜optional extras.â€™
Help people who canâ€™t leave home

If you know someone who is over 65 or has a pre-existing medical condition, reach out and see if they need anything next time you go shopping. You could make them a meal or leave a small gift or care package at their door. Even giving them a call or leaving them a nice note can brighten their day.
Shop online locally

Find out if local businesses have online stores and purchase products. Alternatively, find out if you can buy a gift voucher to use when restrictions are lifted. If you are struggling to think of a gift idea for Motherâ€™s Day, a gift voucher from one of her favourite local businesses could be a good option.
Donate blood
Even in these strange times, blood and plasma are still needed in hospitals. If you can do so safely, consider donating blood. Check your eligibility here.
Make sure the news you share is from a reputable source

Rumours are flying about COVID-19, including incorrect advice about supposed â€˜treatmentsâ€™ or conspiracies about its origin. Check the news you share is from a trusted source â€“ a good way to do this can be to look at multiple news sites (eg. ABC, SBS, The Guardian) and see if they are all reporting similar facts on a topic. If many good resources agree, it is likely that the news is correct. Check our news page for a variety of diverse news sources.

blogPosts.title: Planning a road to recovery: How will COVID-19 restrictions ease in Australia?
blogPosts.summary: As Australia succeeds in slowing the spread of COVID-19 to the community, with cases in the nation nearing single digits each day, the national cabinet will be discussing plans to ease restrictions on Friday this week.  In this piece we will postulate what would be discussed in this meeting, as Australia plans for a road to recover from COVID-19.

text_1: Australiaâ€™s social distancing measures have had great success in curbing the number of active cases in Australia, with most cases nearing zero or single digits this week. This has prompted the National Cabinet to shift its plans to consider discussing relaxing restrictions a week earlier than expected, from May 11 to this Friday May 8.
What do we need to do for restrictions to be eased?

The Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) has proposed 15 conditions to which must be met before social restrictions would be lifted. The ones which are currently being met by Australia are:
olist_1: Community adherence to public health measures, which has been shown by mobility data.
Extensive modelling of the spread of COVID-19.
Expansion of testing capacity.
A mature and large enough public health workforce.
Contact tracing capacity.
A well prepared health system.
Surge capacity in the healthcare system.
ICU-expansion capacity and enough ventilators.
Adequate stock of masks.
Adequate stock of medication.
Workforce training required to prepare healthcare system.
text_2: We are yet to meet the following 4 demands to ease restrictions:

1. Advances in technology for contact tracing, data collection and analysis
    Since the launch of the COVIDSafe App on 27 April 2020, there has been 4 million downloads.
  2. Securing and strengthening the supply of personal protective equipment (PPE)
    The status of each state and territories stock of gloves and gowns are yet to be confirmed. There are also needs for further modelling and an assessment on the security of supply lines.
  3. Increased surveillance and new testing strategy
    There are needs for an expansion of disease surveillance and testing. Sero-surveillance is a long term goal, and requires further development.
  4. Providing resources for increased surveillance
    The Australian National Disease Surveillance Plan for COVID-19 has been developed and will continue to be updated.
What else is there to discuss?

When restrictions will be lifted depends on the number of cases. While states and territories have started to lift social restrictions beyond those proposed by the national cabinet. (see here and our social restrictions section in the information panel) the National Cabinet is yet to propose their recommendations. Australia is in a unique position, in that it has two viable options. The first is to completely eliminate all active cases in the country before lifting any major state or border restrictions. This would be attained when all cases fall to zero for approximately 2 weeks.

Australia is in a lucky position in which this is possible as some states have already eradicated the disease. However, this is difficult to achieve and will mean that lockdown will have to continue beyond mid-May, possibly for another 30 days. The second is to suppress the cases of the disease below the capacity of health systems. However this method is likely to lead to spikes in local cases, for example, the resurgence of disease in Singapore. Perhaps, it might be helpful to consider other experimental choices, for example a recent proposal in which people are allowed to move within disconnected areas such as suburbs and districts, which are progressively joined together as the spread is contained, this is similar to what has been done in Wuhan.
It is also important to discuss how Australia is going to address the long term socio-economic impact COVID-19 has on Australia and the world.

• The pandemic has evidently led our world economy into a recession as well as devastated retail, leisure and hospitality industries. In Australia, according to the new treasury analysis, the shutdown has cost the economy $4 billion each week.
  • COVID-19 has caused countless migrant workers to lose their jobs.
  • Market tampering and stockpiling have caused an increase in food prices and affects the most vulnerable.
  • In Australia, the closure of schools have disrupted childrenâ€™s education and put demand on work/life balance especially for women. In other parts of the world, the interruption in school learning can potentially result in more child labourers and a rise in child marriage. Consequently, leading to a negative impact on the countryâ€™s growth.
  • The pandemic is also affecting those who are already disadvantaged in the society such as the homeless, those in prison, the indigenous, the elderly and the disabled. For example, people with disability have been excluded from COVID-19 compensation payments and endangered indigenous languages are already being forgotten.

While we have seen positive impact on the environment due to COVID-19, this effect will only be short term unless countries persist to the 2030 agenda for sustainable development and the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. This may be a good time for Australia to adhere to the sustainable development goals mentioned previously.

The COVID-19 pandemic has put the world through a devastating test. How Australia responds and adapt to the situation is a matter of life and death which could change its global position and will be forever written in history.
Note: This piece was written and updated on the 5th of May, 2020 and may not account for new developments beyond this date.

blogPosts.title: Weekly Fitness: Calisthenics
blogPosts.summary: Weight training is arguably one of the most popular workouts at the gym. While we are stuck at home due to COVID-19, Calisthenics is one of the best substitutes for that! The only tool youâ€™ll need is your own body weight! In todayâ€™s blog post, we have included some easy exercises to help everyone stay fit and healthy during quarantine! ðŸ’ª

text_1: Weekly Fitness: Calisthenics

This weekâ€™s fitness focus will be on Calisthenics; arguably the best substitute for hitting weights at the gym. In the simplest terms, calisthenics is resistance training with your body weight, and is an effective means that promotes muscle development and strength. Muscle and strength build from resistance, and your body weight is the perfect quarantine tool to maintain those gains youâ€™ve worked so hard to grow over the years!
Here are some exercises to target muscle groups:

Chest and Arms
  • Push ups: Regular push ups can be altered by spreading out your hands. The closer together they are, the more your inner muscles in your chest will be worked, and vice versa.
  • Incline push ups: Perform regular push ups but elevate your feet with a chair, your bed or a bench. This will help to target your upper chest muscles.

Back
  • Chin-ups: This is the best mass-building exercise for your back. Again, you can change the width of your grip to target different back muscles.
  • Hyperextensions: A great way to target your lower back, you can perform this on the edge of your bed and with someone holding your feet in place to ensure safety.

Legs
  • Straight leg deadlifts: You can perform this with additional weights such as rice bags. Always maintain a straight back when performing deadlifts.
  • Lunges: Focus on going as low and long as possible. You can also add weights such as rice bags and gallon water bottles.
  • Squats: Focus again on going as deep as possible and stay down for a few seconds before coming back up. Squats and lunges are great exercises for your quads.

There are plenty of other resources online for complete circuits and workouts, namely on YouTube. Channels such as â€˜Frank Medranoâ€™ and â€˜OFFICIALTHENXâ€™ have complete guides for all levels, from beginner all the way up to professional. Check them out for full demonstrations on all the above exercises plus more!

blogPosts.title: Flu Vaccinations and their importance during COVID-19
blogPosts.summary: In todayâ€™s blog post, we present you a few good reasons why everyone should get their flu vaccination and its importance during a time like this!

text_1: With winter on the horizon, flu season is rapidly approaching. In 2019 there were over 900 flu-related deaths, and this combined with the threat of COVID-19 could prove a recipe for disaster.

Symptomatically, Influenza and coronavirus present very similarly, and cause the most harm to our vulnerable members of the community â€“ the elderly and those who are immunosuppressed. Every year sees an increased pressure on our healthcare system as we deal with outbreaks of influenza, but with the coronavirus already putting a strain on the system, there are fears that a flu outbreak will push healthcare services beyond capacity. Further, there is the risk of individuals contracting both COVID-19 and the flu â€“ a deadly combination.

Without a vaccine for COVID-19, we must seek ways to mitigate this potentially devastating combination. Fortunately, each year we have a new flu vaccine. For those in high risk groups such as those aged under 5 or over 65, the flu vaccine is fully funded by the government. For anyone else, the flu vaccine costs roughly $15-20, and can be administered at most pharmacies.

Vaccinations are important at the best of times, but with both the flu and coronavirus posing a threat to Australians, it has never been so important to safeguard yourself and others around you by getting a flu vaccination. Demand for vaccines is high, and bookings are essential, but appointments are over in a matter of minutes. Getting vaccinated will help protect yourself and others, as well as help reduce the impact on our already stretched healthcare system.
Some pharmacists offering a flu vaccine:
ulist_1: Amcal Pharmacy
Terry White Chemmart

blogPosts.title: COVIDSafe App
blogPosts.summary: The Australian government has recently released the COVIDSafe app. The blog post today will cover what it is and how you can get the app today.

text_1: The Australian government has recently released the COVIDSafe app, which is used to track people who have been in close contact with a person who has COVID-19. This app is an important step in helping reduce the number of cases of COVID-19 and will help lift the current restrictions imposed.
How does the app work?
When you download the app, you are prompted to enter your personal information and will be assigned a unique encrypted reference code.

The app will recognise other devices with the COVIDSafe app installed and when their Bluetooth is turned on. If you encounter another person with the app, it will record the date, time, distance, duration of the contact and the other personâ€™s user code.

If someone does test positive for COVID-19, then the app can help aid the tracking of people who have been in close contact with them. This would then allow health officials to provide advice to those who have been exposed.
How do I download the app?
The app is currently available on the App Store and Google Play Store. You can simply download the app and start your registration!
Privacy concerns

There have been concerns regarding the privacy of your data within the app. The Australian government has assured that the data is protected and only state and territory health authorities can access the information for tracing potential contacts with an infected user.
After the pandemic, users of the app will be prompted to delete the app and the information that has been stored will be destroyed.

At the moment, when deleting the COVIDSafe app on your phone, your information will not be removed from the storage system. However, it will be destroyed at the end of the pandemic and for now users can request for their data to be deleted here.
Downloading the app is quick and easy! So get it today to make sure that you and your loved ones are protected ðŸ’œ.
Sources:
https://www.pm.gov.au/media/covidsafe-new-app-slow-spread-coronavirus
https://www.health.gov.au/resources/apps-and-tools/covidsafe-app

blogPosts.title: Hand sanitiser and COVID-19 â€“ what you need to know
blogPosts.summary: With Hand Sanitisers running out in stores, people have taken to making their own DIY Hand Sanitisers. Learn more about the risks and why it might be best to hold off on making your own for now.

text_1: Empty shelves of hand sanitiser have become a common sight in recent times as people rush to protect themselves from COVID-19. Amidst the panic, some people have turned to DIY solutions to ensure they have hand sanitiser on hand. The question is, are these solutions effective, or even safe?

Most experts agree that an alcohol-based hand sanitiser needs to be at least 60% alcohol to be effective, however research is still being conducted on the minimum concentration needed to destroy SARS-CoV-2 (the virus responsible for COVID-19). It is important to note that viruses like SARS-CoV-2 can be deactivated by 60% ethanol sanitisers (once the virus is deactivated it cannot infect you). SARS-CoV-2 is known have a fat and protein layers that protect the viral core.

Hand sanitiser works by â€˜unravellingâ€™ the protective shell that encases the core, thus making the virus ineffective. A recent study found that the COVID-19 virus can be successfully deactivated by a sanitiser containing 80% ethanol, which is one of the most common active ingredients in hand sanitiser. Additionally, another recent publication indicated that a concentration of 70% ethanol was adequate to deactivate the virus.

With these ethanol concentrations in mind, it is worth analysing some of the top google search results for â€˜DIY hand sanitiserâ€™ to see if any of these solutions could be useful given the information currently available about SARS-CoV-2.

Top Google autocomplete results indicate that people are interested in recipes that include essential oils. DoTerra is a company known for selling essential oils; their recipe contains aloe vera gel, water, vitamin E oil and their own DoTerra On Guard product (a blend of essential oils). Adding rubbing alcohol to this recipe is â€˜optional.â€™ It is important to note that essential oils are not useful in destroying SARS-CoV-2, and so this recipe would not be effective without the alcohol. Even with the alcohol, the concentration would be unlikely to have any effect, as rubbing alcohol varies widely in concentration so itâ€™s impossible to know the concentration â€“ and therefore the efficacy â€“ of the final product.

Other recipes using household items such as vinegar or vodka are also ineffective. Vinegar is not concentrated enough to have a significant effect on the virus. Vodka and many other spirits typically only contain 40% ethanol, so this concentration is not nearly high enough to be effective against SARS-CoV-2.

The World Health Organisation has published hand sanitiser recipes for use primarily in developing countries where access to commercial hand sanitiser is extremely limited. However, their primary recommendation is still to wash your hands with soap and water wherever possible, and to only use hand sanitiser when soap and water isnâ€™t immediately available - ensuring the sanitiser is alcohol-based.

With all this information in mind, maybe hold off on trying out the newest DIY recipe you found. Itâ€™s safest to wash your hand thoroughly for 20 seconds, stay home and save the sanitiser for emergencies only.

blogPosts.title: COVID-19 Surface Lifespan and Ways to Limit Its Survival Time
blogPosts.summary: Here is some information on Coronavirus's lifespan on different surfaces, and some ways to limit the survival of the virus in our environments.

text_1: There is still much to learn about the novel coronavirus but here is some information on the virusâ€™ surface lifespan and ways to limit the survival of the virus in our environments.

Coronavirus can persist on surfaces from a few hours up to several days. Its lifespan varies depending on different conditions such as type of surface as well as the temperature and humidity level of the environment. It is very easy for someone infected to spread virus particles through coughing or touching which leaves the virus on surfaces and other people. This makes it extremely important to clean our hands and disinfect surfaces that we come into contact with.
Know the Difference
Cleaning removes germs from surfaces. It does not kill germs but lowers their numbers and the risk of spreading infection.
Disinfecting uses chemicals to kill germs on surfaces. It effectively further lowers the risk of spreading infection if performed after cleaning.
Practise Routine Cleaning of Frequently Touched Surfaces

• General: doorknobs, handles, light switches, desks and tables
  • Electronics: remote controls, keyboards, phone, laptop and tablets
  • Bathroom: toilets and sinks
How to clean hard (non-porous) surfaces?

• Wear disposal gloves when cleaning and disinfecting surfaces.
  • Discard gloves after EACH cleaning.
  • Gloves should be dedicated for cleaning and disinfecting surfaces and SHOULD NOT be used for other purposes.
  • Clean hands IMMEDIATELY after removing gloves.
  • If surfaces are dirty, clean with detergent or soap and water first before disinfection.
  • Use bleach solution (see below for more information).
How to clean soft (porous) surfaces?
Examples: carpeted floor, rugs, drapes, clothes
• If possible, wash launder items using the warmest appropriate water setting and dry them completely after.
How to clean electronics?

• Use alcohol-based wipes or sprays containing at least 70% alcohol to disinfect.
  • Dry surfaces thoroughly after.
Hand Hygiene

• Wash hands with soap and water for 20 seconds â€“ refer to the hand-washing video provided on our Info page.
  • Use hand sanitiser containing at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.
What You Can Use
Soap and Water

• This is your first line of defence to remove the virus from surfaces.
  • Soap can lift the virus from surfaces and then water will rinse it off.
Bleach

• The active ingredient in bleach â€“ sodium hypochlorite is very effective in killing the virus.
  • Make sure to leave the bleach on surfaces for 10 â€“ 15 minutes for it to work.
  • Give the surface a wipe with a clean cloth after.
Prepare a bleach solution

• 5 tablespoons (1/3 cup) of bleach per gallon of water
  • 4 teaspoons of bleach per quart of water
Antiseptic Surface Wipes

• Physically removes germs through the pressure you apply.
  • The germs then be attached to the wipe.
  • Leaves a layer of antiseptic on the surface that can kill germs and coronavirus that infect dogs. However, this does not apply to the spread of human coronavirus.
Hand Sanitiser

• The main ingredient is ethanol.
  • The concentration in the hand sanitiser is very important.
  • It has to be 60 â€“ 70% or it cannot kill the virus effectively.
Other Information
Vinegar, tea tree oil and other natural products are NOT recommended. There are no evidence of these ingredients being effective in killing coronavirus.
Reminder

• Make sure you air out the spaces you are spending time in regularly.
  • When you open the window, you disperse and reduce the amount of virus in the air.
  • This means that by opening your windows, you can reduce the risk of infection for others.
We are living in uncertain times but it is reassuring to know that we have some ways to fight COVID-19 in our environments.
How long can COVID-19 live on surfaces?

Surface Duration Includes
air 3 hours moisture from coughing/sneezing, fog and dust
copper 4 hours taps, drawer handles, coins, etc.
cardboard 24 hours packaging, mail. (post unlikely to transmit virus)
non-porous surfaces 4+ days handrails, doorknobs, elevator buttons, lightswitches, etc.
plastic 2-3 days bottles, plastic bags, containers, packaging, etc.
glass 9 days mobile phones, windows, bottles, etc.

blogPosts.title: Coronavirus Myths and Hoaxes
blogPosts.summary: As COVID-19 has continued to develop and spread, a lot of misinformation and hoaxes have also come on the rise. In todayâ€™s blog post, we have provided 10 myths of the virus.

text_1: Over the last couple of months, there has been a plethora of misleading information and hoaxes that have circulated around social media and the wider internet. It is important that information like this doesnâ€™t become treated as fact, as it can be harmful, with irrelevant and inaccurate information hindering the control of the spread of COVID-19.
Here are 10 of them busted:
olist_1: Not all face masks can protect against COVID-19: Healthcare workers wear professional masks and other equipment to protect themselves from infection. For general purpose usage, disposable masks are unlikely to block tiny viral particles. However, a cloth mask is able to prevent the spread of these droplets. The CDC and other health professional recommend that all people wear cloth masks in public if it is difficult to maintain social distancing. When wearing a mask, it is essential to continue with other precautions too, such as not touching your face.

5G mobile networks DO NOT spread COVID-19: Viruses like COVID-19 are spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes, and then transmitted through others touching a contaminated surface. They cannot travel through radio waves and mobile networks. COVID-19 is prevalent in countries that do not have 5G mobile networks, and this myth has been debunked by leading scientists and researchers around the world.

Injecting disinfectant CANNOT KILL COVID-19: This is by far one of the deadliest hoaxes, especially prevalent in the US. Injecting any corrosive substance of alcohol based disinfectant can be extremely harmful, and in many cases, fatal.

Drinking alcohol does not protect you from COVID-19: Not only will drinking alcohol not protect you against COVID-19 and other viruses, but excessive alcohol consumption can lead to other health problems, including increasing your risk of liver damage.

Eating garlic does not protect you from COVID-19: Although garlics are healthy that have antimicrobial properties, there is no current evidence to support that eating garlic has protected people from the virus.
Antibiotics are ineffective against COVID-19: COVID-19 is a virus. Antibiotics work against bacteria, and therefore, should not be used as a means of prevention of treatment.

Spraying chlorine and alcohol on the skin does not kill COVID-19 if you already have it: If the virus is already present inside the body, applying chlorine or any disinfectant on your body will not kill the virus. It can also be harmful, as substances such as chlorine are corrosive, and can be especially harmful if it enters the eyes or mouth.

Parcels from China cannot spread COVID-19: From previous analysis and research, scientists know that COVID-19 cannot survive long on objects, such as letters and packages. People receiving packages from China are not at risk of contracting COVID-19, but precaution should still be taken due to local handling.

Vaccines against pneumonia cannot protect you from COVID-19: Vaccines against pneumonia, such as Haemophilus influenza Type B (Hib) and pneumococcal vaccines, do not provide protection against COVID-19.

Thermal scanners cannot diagnose COVID-19: Thermal scanners have the ability to detect if someone has a fever or not. However, other illnesses such as the seasonal flu can also lead to fevers and higher temperatures.

blogPosts.title: Online education during COVID-19
blogPosts.summary: With education moving online having access to a range of resources and information can set you up for success! Check out the blog post for tips and tricks to make your life easier through digital schooling.

text_1: Online education has become a part of the new normal, and despite the news that schools might return soon in some capacity, it is likely that some degree of online learning will remain in place for a while. With that in mind, weâ€™ve collated some helping resources to help parents and kids succeed at online education.
Each state has slightly different recommendations and guidelines, but here a few common things to keep in mind.
olist_1:
Set up a learning environment:
Find a space that quiet and comfortable. Most states recommend a space outside the bedroom to ensure adequate supervision can be easily provided. This could be a kitchen table or in the lounge, wherever suits your home and family.

Establish a routine:
Figure out times in which assigned tasks will be completed, ensuring that there are a number of breaks included. A studentâ€™s day does not need to follow a normal school timetable if that doesnâ€™t work for them, but some kind of consistent schedule is key.

Find other resources to help:
Many resources have been released since the outset of online learning to suit children of all ages. A few tools are linked below that are worth looking at for additional help with schooling.
text_2: Here is a resource to help keep students engaged at home.
The ABC has lessons online on a range of subjects in both primary and secondary school. You can find them here and here.
Here is a huge list of resources if something more specific is needed.

blogPosts.title: Weekly Fitness with HIIT
blogPosts.summary: Todayâ€™s blog post will be this weekâ€™s fitness, focusing on High Interval Intensive Training, or HIIT. No equipment needed again, just yourself and a dedicated mindset! ðŸ’ª

text_1: Following on from last weekâ€™s cardio, this weekâ€™s fitness focus will be on another form of aerobic exercise, which again, doesnâ€™t require any equipment to perform. High-Intensity Interval Training, or HIIT, are workouts that combine short bursts of intense exercise with short periods of rest or lower-intensity exercise.

HIIT promises the best workout in the least amount of time, and is widely considered to be one of the most effective methods of exercise for weight loss and fat burning, as well as having the ability to â€˜metabolically charge the bodyâ€™.
What exactly is HIIT?

When researchers and scientists talk about HIIT, they typically refer to bursts of super-charged physical activity, where a personâ€™s heart rate reaches at least 80% of its maximum capacity. The most well-established benefit of HIIT is heart health, with a short training time being able to provide the same benefits as much longer, continuous forms of aerobic exercise.

Interval training causes metabolic disturbance, and can result in the body burning calories at a higher rate up to 48-72 hours after your workout. HIIT can also reduce insulin resistance, improve cardiac function, and most importantly, improved VO2 max, which is a measure of endurance that calculates the maximum volume of oxygen a body can use.
Here are a few Interval workout you can try at home yourself!
ulist_1:
Sprint Interval Training:
Any form of normal cardio exercises can be adapted into a HIIT workout. One of the easiest and most convenient ways is a sprint interval workout. Spring at 80% for 10 seconds, and rest for 30-60 seconds, then repeat. Gradually increase intensity during your sprints, and repeat 5-15 times. This is a great exercise for building cardiovascular health, especially when done on an incline.

Burpee circuit:
- Standings or bounce squats as many reps in 30 seconds
- Jumping jacks - 60 reps
- Burpees - 20 reps
Complete the circuit 4 times, resting one minute after the burpees.

Jump rope interval workout:
- Push ups - 30 reps
- Front plank - 1 min 30 seconds
- Jump rope - 1 minute
Complete the circuit 4 times, resting one minute after the jump rope.

Ab interval workout:
- Crunches - 20 reps
- Bicycle crunches - 1 minute
- Flutter kicks - 20 reps
- Leg raises - 30 reps
- Superman - Hold for 1 minute
Complete the circuit 4 times, resting one minute after Superman.
text_2: There are plenty of online resources for HIIT, with YouTube being a great source for proper form, as well as having videos for all fitness levels. If you have any pre-existing conditions such as asthma or heart-related, consult a doctor before you start a program.
As Australia is starting to loosen restrictions on quarantine, hopefully this will mean that we are able to go outside more and stay fit.

blogPosts.title: Non-therapeutic COVID-19 interventions
blogPosts.summary: COVID-19 studies on vaccines and drug treatments have all the attention by news media and funding bodies. In this piece we will explore some other COVID-19 studies which have been left in the dark.

text_1: In our race to stop COVID-19, vaccines and potential drug treatments have been the belle of the ball â€“ receiving the most attention and funding from government, private and media bodies. However, the potential results of vaccine and drug developments are still to come to fruition. What is currently helping slow the spread of the virus, is our combined efforts in social distancing, hand-washing, and wearing protective equipment. Collectively these mitigation strategies are known as non-therapeutic interventions.

We will all have come across one of the interventions in our lifetime. Some of these interventions can seem like common sense with guidance from health authorities regarding these interventions are often very broad and left up to our own interpretation. However, more clear and concise instructions are warranted. How should I wash my hands if I have an irritable skin disease? What is the difference between wearing a surgical mask compared to cloth masks? Out of all these interventions - which one is the best? A lack of clarity in public health announcements is often because evidence-based guidelines on these matters often do not reach a consensus after systemic evaluation and studies into these strategies are often too dispersed and unregulated to result in clear outcomes. Therefore, further research on non-therapeutic interventions warrants funding and attention. This is needed such that before the next pandemic, we can have trustful and transparent evidence, to help decision-makers plan and unify their responses, without substantial divergence and hesitation.

In this blog, we will review some previous and emerging literature with regard to non-therapeutic interventions, to give them awareness. Please note, some of these studies are pre-prints and have not been peer-reviewed. All articles come from www.medrxiv.org or news sources.
How these studies are conducted
Usually, these non-therapeutic intervention studies can be broadly characterized into three categories:
ulist_1: experimental studies in which different protective equipment made from different materials are assessed in terms of how they protect against the virus
observation studies, where researchers use past documented data/studies and modelling methods to project and evaluate the efficiency of the intervention method.

randomized controlled trials, where researchers separate participants into certain groups, with different experimental conditions to perform different interventions in a systematic and control manner. Results are compared between groups.
text_2: Current studies on COVID-19

The studies of most demand have been modelling studies that try to project how major non-intervention strategies, such as lockdown, school closures, and social distancing affect the spread of the infections, as well as other critical factors like keeping ICU cases low. They also usually involve analysis of whether earlier introduction of these social interventions could help prevent the spread of the virus.

Seminal studies coming from our news source include new research by the University of Sydney as well as the government's own projections, done in collaboration with Doherty Institute [1][2]. Riding on from the political controversies about the effectiveness of border closures, a major focus has also been to determine which of the major non-intervention strategies, such as lockdown, school closures, and social results have been the most effective at slowing the spread. While some reports hesitated to determine which single non-therapeutic intervention reduced the rate of disease [1],[2], others take a strong stance and support the fact that travel restriction had less success than population movement and close contact in China [1].

Another set of studies focuses on how the virus spreads in the environment. One example is a major study from the New England Journal of Medicine [1] which characterized the stability of COVID-19 in different surfaces. A review of the current literature on the topic is also available here [1].

Another category studies resource allocation of non-therapeutic equipment and assesses when they may show shortages. One study uses the Global burden of disease, injuries, and risk factor data to determine how accessible handwashing stations are in low-income countries [1]. This study uses prediction models to show how sufficient supplies of facemasks are in China, under the current guidelines, indicating there is only a 1 week supply which can be mitigated by scaling production by 42% [1].

Of the most pressing concern for other studies, is to evaluate whether or not face masks should be used as a non-therapeutic intervention. This comes from the many discrepancies about the usage of face masks from different authorities. While the use of surgical masks has been promoted in Asian countries, the World health organization, Europe and North America do not promote this practice. Some including the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Bosnia, and Herzegovina, and Australia however, have changed their recommendations. The following article provides an extensive systematic review of the current literature regarding facemasks, with an effective overview of how masks' effectiveness changes depending on the setting (household, facemasks), effectiveness in community settings and mass gatherings, and how it can interfere with ordinary activities [1].

As one of the main problems deterring health organizations from recommending facemasks is the shortage of supply, different strategies have also been proposed. The first possible way is exploring ways to disinfect used masks, so they can be reused. Some of these studies examine cheap, easily deployable disinfection practices [1]. Others repurpose sanitization machines for mask disinfection [1]. With different health officials recommending home-made masks, the effectiveness of different house-hold fabrics used by home-made masks to filter particles has also been questioned [1]. Another examines how studies show how effective the usage of home-made masks is in preventing environmental contamination, rather than protecting the individual from infection.
How to move forward and what needs to be done

While there does seem to be some amount of studies being published in regards to non-therapeutic interventions, we can always do better and in many cases, it is still not enough. Here are some of the key limitations we believe might be missing from the picture.

Firstly, we need to determine how major non-intervention strategies in middle and low-income countries prevent disease. Some studies are already in place, for example, estimation studies in Colombia [1]. The validity of these studies, however, is coupled with problems due to poor testing capabilities, and the possible real number of cases can be estimated through other methods such as assessing sewage systems for COVID-19 particles.

Most studies currently are either experimental or observational, and there are no random clinical trials (RCT) to assess the effectiveness of these measures. The most pressing gaps in knowledge that are coming from this epidemic, is our lack of consensus about the validity of masks. However aside from assessing masks and their use in curbing COVID-19 infections, there are also numerous other that deserve attention, such as handwashing and eye protection equipment. What are some alternatives if these resources are not available? What resources can be provided to individuals with allergies to the product used? What are the consequences of wearing these equipment long term?

Aside from addressing new questions, it is important to note that, conducting poor quality RCT after pandemics had been a recurring pattern. A new systematic study[1] assesses the validity of randomized clinical trials conducted in relation to influenza and influenza-like illness after the 2003 SARS epidemic. Of over 2000 clinical trials, all but 100 were immediately omitted from the assessment. Of these 100 studies, there was no significant effect on the use of almost every non-therapeutic intervention which included masks, handwashing, eye protection for influenza. This does not suggest nothing we do actually but helps us, but highlights that much of studies till now have been too low quality and messy to allow us to drive any positive conclusions.

So how would we correct the mistakes from the past? It has been suggested one possible way would be to have more transparency in randomized clinical trials in regards to non-therapeutic interventions. This in fact is a very broad problem in which all trials performed under any context, aside from vaccines or drugs have been poorly regulated, and they require registration in most countries, especially in the US and EU. Transparency in what studies have been conducted is the first step towards standardising the way these trials are conducted [1]. Perhaps, with the number of new dashboard technologies that could be utilised to monitor and track upcoming trials, similar to those proposed for important clinical trials.

Aside from randomised clinical trials, what can we do to improve observational studies? Since these studies analyse patterns in data, after the event has passed, documented case information is important. However, the government and others globally provide clear uniform ways of updating case numbers, without consistencies between every province and country. Typically researchers judge the specific material used for protective coverings from government directions and also pictures of the public and what a majority uses. Explicit, direct instructions on how to implement interventions would also be appreciated, such that there is less guessing work.

Lastly, research on the best way to educate and inform the public on how to comply with non-intervention measures as well as the importance of these measures, is heavily needed. We did not come across any of these studies in the current pre-prints, but this is a critical factor especially in countries where there might be poor literacy, as well as to educate and take care of those in the public who might be unable to understand these guidance due to different restrictions.
The article which inspired this blog piece:
The Conversation - What if the vaccine or drugs donâ€™t save us? Plan B for coronavirus means research on alternatives is urgently needed.

blogPosts.title: Activities for Children to pass time
blogPosts.summary: With families stuck at home and children full of energy but nowhere to release it, here are a few awesome resources for your kids to participate in and have some fun!

text_1: Need to entertain your little ones while stuck at home? Fret not! Many parents have been in your place- and to help with that weâ€™ve compiled a list of digital experiences to try out with our favourite iso-buddies this week!
olist_1:
Hey There Hello:
Hey There Hello is a platform for parents, grandparents, teens (and adults too) to book short video-conference calls with entertainers all over. Enjoy a range of one-on-one experiences from yoga to art classes, story-telling and even celebrity impersonations!

Kodable:
Probably our developersâ€™ top pick, Kodable teaches children coding and creativity in a fun, approachable way. The gameplay is self-guided, and the free trial runs for seven days!

Bring Home The Fun by Hasbro:
By family-favourite Habro, explore resources, including tips for family playtime, activity challenges to keep kids occupied, and even ideas for using games and toys you might already have at home!
text_2: We hope these have inspired you during these dull times! Be sure to stay calm and informed!
Donâ€™t forget to check out the rest of our website for more information, live updates and latest news on COVID-19 in Australia!
#StayCalmStayInformed

blogPosts.title: Hong Kongâ€™s Response to COVID-19
blogPosts.summary: With Covid-19 spreading world-wide, Hong Kong faces a situation similar to the SARS epidemic in 2002-2004. Curious about Hong Kong's keys to success despite facing two waves of cases? Click to find out more.

text_1: Lessons Learnt from SARS in 2003

Ever since the devastating SARS outbreak in 2003, the residents Hong Kong have nurtured robust hygiene habits in the hopes of preventing the nightmare from reoccurring. In Hong Kong alone, SARS infected over 1,700 people and killed nearly 300. Since then, people in Hong Kong have never abandoned their sanitation routines.

After the experience of SARS, Hong Kong doubled down to prepare for the next crisis and use its hard-won lessons to combat COVID-19. The Special Administrative Region had set up response capabilities and a preparedness plans. Hong Kong has had a Preparedness Plan for Influenza Pandemic in place for many years. It details 3 response levels â€“ Alert, Serious and Emergency which aim to clearly demonstrate the current disease situation to the public and guide the cityâ€™s response.

When coronavirus broke out early this year, people in Hong Kong did not think twice â€“ they  quickly put on their facemasks, slathered on hand sanitiser and obediently stayed indoors. People were accustomed to wearing masks for every sniffle or cough and getting their  temperature taken when arriving at the Hong Kong airport.
The First Wave
On January 4, COVID-19 was declared to be SERIOUS under the pandemic plan.
On January 25, the outbreak response level was raised to EMERGENCY.

The city and its people responded quickly to COVID-19 and practised their sanitation routines learnt from SARS in 2003. By early March, the city seemed to have the outbreak contained, with nearly zero new cases and only a total of 4 deaths.
The Second Wave

As the outbreak appeared to be contained in Hong Kong, people emerged from their homes to resume life. Hong Kong began to welcome home residents and students who had been stuck overseas. Since then, there has been a resurgence of confirmed cases. However, the jump in cases was not surprising to scientists in Hong Kong because they knew that the pandemic would come in waves.

Since March 28, restaurants in Hong Kong had been limited to operate 50% normal capacity with no more than 4 at a table. Restaurant workers are required to take patronsâ€™ temperatures at the door and provide them with hand sanitiser.

On April 20, it was the first day in 6 weeks that Hong Kong reported no new cases of COVID-19. It seemed that the city may have successfully contained the second wave of coronavirus cases triggered by overseas residents returning home.
Against All Odds
The outbreak could have easily gone out of control in Hong Kong.

1. COVID-19 emerged around Lunar New Year when many people often travel across the region. The city is closely interconnected with mainland China through a shared border and has direct flights to Wuhan.
2. Hong Kong is a densely populated city. The moment you leave your home, you are surrounded by people. It is extremely difficult to avoid getting infected.
Keys to Success
The city should be praised for its decision to respond aggressively from the outset. By February 1, Hong Kong had proactively implemented travel restrictions on people coming from mainland China.
Hong Kong fought the pandemic through aggressive testing, isolating infected people as well as tracing and quarantining people they came in contact with.
ulist_1: There were around 14,000 tests done by Hong Kong, which is one of the highest testing rates in the world.
Those who were tested positive were hospitalised regardless of whether they had COVID-19 symptoms or not in order prevent them infecting others.

Close contacts of confirmed cases and all recent returnees are required to self-quarantine at home for 14 days and wear an electronic wristband that can track their whereabouts. Violators are subjected to fines and jail terms.
text_2: The people of Hong Kong should be commended for their responsible actions and routine sanitisation. They knew how serious an outbreak could get and were prepared to do what was necessary to prevent the same outcome as SARS in 2003 without any questions.
Although it is still too early to declare victory, Hong Kong has done extremely well against all odds.
Story of Sven Johannsen
A little insight of how people in Hong Kong act in response to COVID-19:

Sven Johannsen is originally from Germany but has been a Hong Kong resident for 5 years. Every morning, he puts on his N95 mask for his four-stop subway ride to work. He avoids touching buttons or railings and uses his knee when using the elevator. He also religiously applies hand sanitiser after every contact. Sven believes that Hong Kong is the safest place in the world now because every single person takes it seriously.

blogPosts.title: Pride in the age of Covid-19
blogPosts.summary: Throughout this Covid-19 outbreak, LGBTQIA+ people are facing unique challenges. Find out how to get support, and see what's happening with Pride in 2020.

text_1: Itâ€™s no surprise that LGBTQIA+ people face unique challenges under current social distancing requirements. Being forced to move back in with unaccepting family, facing unemployment and potentially homelessness are real challenges the community will contend with in the coming months. In addition, over 200 pride events have been cancelled for the obvious safety risk they pose due to Covid-19. In this time of great uncertainty, support is available and accessible to community members.
Want to talk? - Qlife offers anonymous peer support to queer people through either webchat or telephone.
Want information? - The National LGBTI Health Alliance provides a huge amount of information about different support services and information available to LGBTQIA+ peoples.

Working remotely during Covid-19 - ILGA World has compiled a list of secure platforms to assist people with working from home safely. It also has some recommendations for LGBTQIA+ media to help pass the time.

Whatâ€™s happening with Pride in 2020? - Pride is online in 2020! Worldwide Pride organisations have announced that on the 27th of June, Pride celebrations will be livestreamed. The livestreaming platform is yet to be announced.
Please comment if you are aware of any additional resources people might find helpful!

blogPosts.title: Rapid Testing in Australia
blogPosts.summary: Since the beginning of Covid-19, the importance and necessity of easily accessible and accurate testing has been emphasised greatly as many countries have failed to provide adequate testing. One Melbourne-based company is paving the way for a solution to this problem.

text_1: As Australia and the world seeks to contain COVID-19, a key barrier to containment has been the testing delay and backlog. With this in mind, the development of rapid test kits or point of care tests could pave the way for widespread, on-the-spot testing. This will not only allow us to get a far more accurate picture of the number of active cases, but also will facilitate the tracing of cases and allow essential workers the peace of mind to know when they can return to work and their families if isolating.

One such company is MD Solutions, a Melbourne company who received expedited approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), whose test requires just two drops of blood, and needs no laboratory processing before a result can be obtained in just 15 minutes.

Such examples pave the way for temporary testing clinics to be far more easily set up, as well as the opportunity to expand the mobile and drive-through testing facilities which can greatly expand our testing capacity.

There are some concerns relating to the chances of false-negative results, as the rapid test kits test for antibodies associated with the virus rather than the virus itself as is done with RNA testing in a laboratory. However, the dominant view remains that the benefits of rapid testing outweigh these slight concerns.

As with most things these days, we must hope for the best and hope that rapid test kits allow for significant improvements in early detection for those infected, and thus allow quicker isolation and identification of close contacts. In doing so we will be able to more easily trace the virus and reduce its spread.

blogPosts.title: The Story of COVID-19-AU
blogPosts.summary: With the Covid-19 crisis surging up rapidly, a small group of students led by Dr. Chen of Monash Faculty of Information took up the responsibility to create a trustworthy and reliable platform for the Australian Community to learn more about the situation, and find out how to keep them and their community safe.

text_1: Who we are
The COVID-19-AU project was started by Dr. Chungyang Chen and a team of graduate students from Monash Universityâ€™s Faculty of Information Technology.

The aim of this project is to help Australians to stay informed with the rapidly-changing COVID-19 situation. We want to create awareness and educate people about the pandemic by providing real-time data, latest news updates and important information. We update our website as frequently as possible â€“ often once every hour, to provide Australians with the most up-to-date information on COVID-19 in Australia.
What we do

Our website holds a collection of data sourced from official Government websites and news groups from all Australian states, collated together to give an accurate picture of the COVID-19 situation country-wide. There is nothing more dangerous than misinformation in uncertain times like these. We want to create a platform that makes it easy to understand the current situation in Australia as it is very difficult to see the bigger picture just by reading news articles or looking at current data on Government websites.

We present data in many formats to make our website as accessible and useful to everyone. For example, we use interactive geographic data visualisation to help Australians to see infection hotspots on a map and the impact of COVID-19 on Australia as a whole.
Why we do it

We believe that by helping people to be more informed of the situation in Australia and the impact of this pandemic on the country as a whole, Australians will be encouraged to come together as a community to do their part to protect their country such as following Government guidelines to prevent the spread of the outbreak. We also think that it is important for people to understand what data tells us, so that they can appreciate the importance of Government guidelines.
How we've grown

We have been promoting our project on multiple social media platforms, and since then, many new students from multiple Universities around Australia and people working in the IT industry have chosen to volunteer their time to help.

This project has not been easy to manage. Due to COVID-19 restrictions, we are unable to meet up to work on the project together and most of us have never met each other before. We have to rely on constant online communication in order to facilitate collaboration between different teams. However, we are able to overcome our hardships through sharing a common goal of wanting to do our part to help our country and Australians during this difficult time.

This project is entirely run by volunteers and the website is designed for non-commercial use only. For the students working on this project, it is an incredibly opportunity to see how the skills we have learnt during the course of our education can be applied in the real world. More importantly, it is extremely rewarding to know that we have the ability to give back to our society and do our part to help Australia during this crisis.
How you can help

We want to make out website useful to everyone so we always take into consideration usersâ€™ feedbacks and try to implement their feature suggestions. To stay connected with our users, we interact with them through our social media platforms where we update multiple times each day with daily reports and other content to help everyone stay positive during this challenging time. We want to be a supportive community and help each other get through this incredibly challenging time by spreading positivity. We aim to do this by providing hope for Australians and showing that we can combat this outbreak TOGETHER.

Thanks to the efforts of our dedicated team, our website now has over 4 million views. We are still trying to expand our reach so that we can help as many people as possible with this platform. If you would like to support us, please share our website with your friends and family. We hope our website can be a platform that Australians can rely on during this stressful time!
ðŸ’¬ We want to make our website as helpful to you as possible, so please donâ€™t hesitate to provide us with feedback and suggestions here.
Donâ€™t forget to follow us on Social Media to follow our project progress or to connect with us!
Check out our Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.
